channel.title: jMonkeyEngine
channel.description: Have any of you used it for game development in Java? It's like a fork of NetBeans for game design in Java, for those who don't know. Or do you use pure code for your games, program in another language, or not do game programming at all?

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:23, topic:396949”][quote author=lawl_temp link=topic=494108.msg3614559#msg3614559 date=1306869591]
@mitb: no one mentioned browser games but you

and what good is having a game in a browser? (other than casual games, eg. flash games)
im pretty sure most people would prefer to play the game out of the browser (look at runescape & how many used swiftswitch in its day, etc)

aside, though, i said java is a bad platform for 3d game development because:

  1. the available libraries for java are rubbish and
  2. you will never achieve the same performance as with natively compiled code. in 3d games, the difference is massive
    [/quote]

Swiftswitch was made because Jagex didn’t do it right back in the day, now they do, offering a client that fills your screen and even has a full screen option. Anyone can do that so it’s a much better way to distribute your game.

  1. Don’t most/all C/C++ graphics libraries have Java bindings? As to the Java standard library, it’s superior to almost all other standard libraries, especially C and C++.
  2. The performance difference is negligible.

Flash is capable of handling nontrivial networking. SmartFoxServer is a case in point.

Are there any non-trivial games that use it? There are a number of MMORPGs for instance that use Java.[/quote]

Dofus, Gaiaonline’s zOMG!, etc.

Read full topic

aside, though, i said java is a bad platform for 3d game development because:

  1. the available libraries for java are rubbish and
  2. you will never achieve the same performance as with natively compiled code. in 3d games, the difference is massive[/quote]

Swiftswitch was made because Jagex didn’t do it right back in the day, now they do, offering a client that fills your screen and even has a full screen option. Anyone can do that so it’s a much better way to distribute your game.

  1. Don’t most/all C/C++ graphics libraries have Java bindings? As to the Java standard library, it’s superior to almost all other standard libraries, especially C and C++.
  2. The performance difference is negligible.
unlimitedorb:

Flash is capable of handling nontrivial networking. SmartFoxServer is a case in point.

Are there any non-trivial games that use it? There are a number of MMORPGs for instance that use Java.

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Users still use IE6, so yes, I assume plenty of them still don’t have HTML5 support, it takes years for new browser stuff to be well supported, not even taking into account how microsoft chooses to support things.

Read full topic

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Do very few users really have HTML5 support, in the age of self updating browsers? I can understand websockets being unsupported (well, more like off by default), but surely the stats on the core stuff must be pretty high?

Read full topic

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I didn’t want to get into this debate, but your only other alternatives for a browser based game are:

  1. Your own browser plugin. (think Quake Live), not a very good solution.
  2. Flash. Alright for trivial games, I personally dislike it and I don’t think anyone thinks it’s a good option for something relying heavily on networking.
  3. HTML5 + Javascript. Probably a good alternative a few years from now when a decent amount of users have supported browsers. Right now very few users have HTML5 support.

So like I said, for certain projects, certain languages have the most advantages or disadvantages. For a cross-platform, easily deployed and/or browser based game, that needs some networking support, Java is your only option right now.

Read full topic

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Java is great (and indeed, almost your only alternative) for a cross-platform browser based game, or even one that can be played in a browser or without one.

It’s 2011 now.

Read full topic

item.title: jMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“lawl_temp, post:13, topic:396949”][quote author=Imperative link=topic=494108.msg3614291#msg3614291 date=1306853756]

I tried making a game with jME. Thought it was nice. Then I tried OGRE3D, and I will never in my life go back to using the piece of shit that is jME

You use Ogre4j?

no, ogre3d. c++

Oh, what’s your favorite for Java game development?
[/quote]
java is awful for game development. seek alternatives[/quote]
That’s just a ridiculous statement, it’s just as valid an alternative as anything else. Like every program ever made, some languages are better than others for a specific end goal. Java is great (and indeed, almost your only alternative) for a cross-platform browser based game, or even one that can be played in a browser or without one.

Read full topic
